top_categories.workout_context: Badlands’s 497-mile distance demands power production deep into fatigue — the defining challenge of ultra-distance gravel.
Badlands’s desert gravel, alpine passes, technical trails and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Every session at Badlands intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Badlands’s desert gravel, alpine passes demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing Badlands isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
At 497 miles, Badlands rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Badlands — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Badlands when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Badlands’s 52,493ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
Badlands rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Badlands — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on desert gravel, alpine passes, technical trails.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what Badlands’s desert gravel, alpine passes, technical trails delivers on race day.

race_overlay.heat: August in Granada, Andalusia, Spain — August in Andalusia is brutal. Desert sections reach 40-45°C (104-113°F). Pico Veleta at 3,396m can drop to 5-10°C at night with potential freezing. 30-40°C temperature swings in a single day. Afternoon thunderstorms in mountains possible. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before Badlands — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day. Race-day realities: Extreme heat in desert (40°C+).
race_overlay.nutrition: Ultra-distance fueling for 497 miles: 80–100g carbs/hour from mile 1 — don’t wait until you’re hungry. Practice your exact race-day nutrition in every long training ride. Carry backup calories. 497 miles burns 8,000–12,000+ calories — you cannot replace them all, but you must try.
race_overlay.altitude: Badlands with 52,493ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. Alpine cold at altitude.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Badlands demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride desert gravel, alpine passes, technical trails at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: desert gravel, alpine passes, technical mtb trails. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 497 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, VO2max, and Endurance to prepare you for 497 miles of desert gravel, alpine passes, technical trails in Granada, Andalusia, Spain.
